Actinacidiphila polyblastidii is a species of actinobacteria that was isolated from the sludge of an acidic industrial wastewater treatment plant. The species name "polyblastidii" refers to its ability to form multiple bud-like structures, known as blastospores, during its life cycle.

Actinacidiphila polyblastidii is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. It has a characteristic branched, filamentous morphology typical of actinobacteria. The cells are able to grow at acidic pH levels, with an optimal growth pH range between 4.0 and 6.0.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing has placed Actinacidiphila polyblastidii within the family Acidimicrobiaceae, which comprises a group of acidophilic actinobacteria. The genus Actinacidiphila was established to accommodate this species and a few others with similar characteristics.

Actinacidiphila polyblastidii is considered an important member of the microbial communities found in acidic industrial wastewater treatment systems, where it likely plays a role in the degradation of organic compounds and the maintenance of the acidic environment.
